title: Win by Focusing on Your Core Users
description: Shane Murphy-Reuter is the President of Go-To-Market at Calendly, a leading scheduling software platform trusted by millions. With a proven track record in scaling SaaS companies like Intercom and Webflow, Shane brings deep expertise in product-led growth, sales strategy, and category creation. In this episode, he shares how Calendly has evolved beyond scheduling to serve SMBs and solopreneurs through AI-driven relationship management tools. Tune in to learn how focusing on your core users can drive sustainable growth, outpace competitors, and spark innovation in a crowded market. Today we discussed: [00:00] Opening [00:09] Introducing Shane Murphy-Reuter [00:51] Extending Your Core Business [04:47] How Hyperfocus Protects Your Business [06:51] Find your Unique Advantage [10:28] Messaging for Clients with Different Needs [15:05] Shifting Mindset to Deal with Growth [17:00] Incentivizing Sales Teams [19:00] How Will AI Effect Scheduling Software More About Shane Murphy-Reuter: Check out Shane Murphy-Reuter's Website: https://calendly.com/ Connect with Shane Murphy-Reuter on LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/shanemurfy/ Rate, Review, & Follow If you liked this episode, please rate and review the show. title: Bridging the Courage Gap in Your Business
description: Dr. Margie Warrell is a bestselling author, leadership coach, and global authority on courage, risk-taking, and transformational leadership. She‚Äôs worked with Fortune 500 companies, coached C-suite executives, and spoken at the US Congress‚Äîempowering thousands to lead with boldness and integrity. In this episode, we dive into her latest book, The Courage Gap: Five Steps to Braver Action, exploring how fear, self-doubt, and imposter syndrome silently sabotage decision-making and business growth. Margie shares powerful strategies for building your ‚Äúcourage muscle,‚Äù raising your rates with confidence, and taking bold action even amid uncertainty. Today we discussed: [00:00] Opening [00:09] Introduction to Margie Warrell [01:01] What is the Courage Gap? [02:57] The Difference Between Fear-based and Strategic Pausing [05:06] What Role Does Imposter Syndrome Play? title: Hospital stocks gain on safe-haven buying
description: In past one month, most hospital stocks such as Max Healthcare, Apollo Hospitals, Fortis Healthcare, Healthcare Global and Rainbow Children's Medicare, among other, have surged 4.3-19.6% while the benchmark Nifty gained 4.1% in the same period.

title: Federal Reserve can wait on any rate moves: Powell
description: The sharp volatility in financial markets since President Donald Trump announced sweeping tariffs April 2, only to put most of them on hold a week later, has led to speculation about whether the Federal Reserve would soon cut interest rate or take other steps to calm investors.

description: What you eat is likely the best reflection of your gut health, says top nutrition expert Tim Spector.

title: OpenAI updated its safety framework‚Äîbut no longer sees mass manipulation and disinformation as a critical risk
description: OpenAI‚Äôs updated AI safety framework drops key pre-release testing requirements‚Äîincluding for persuasive or manipulative capabilities‚Äîsparking concern among experts.
author: Sharon Goldman, Jeremy Kahn

title: The Conversations You Should Be Having with Your Manager
description: As you advance in your career, you develop the skills to lead teams and manage direct reports. But no matter your role or seniority, you‚Äôll always need to manage those above you and to develop the right relationships to progress. The secret to managing up, says Melody Wilding, is being strategic and thoughtful in several key kinds of conversations with your boss and boss‚Äôs boss‚Äîincluding finding alignment, setting boundaries, getting visibility for your work, and winning a promotion. She explains how the effort pays off both in future opportunities and your day-to-day satisfaction on the job. Wilding is an executive coach and the author of the book¬†Managing Up: How to Get What You Need from the People in Charge.

title: What All Leaders Can Learn from Taylor Swift
description: Whether you're a fan of Taylor Swift or not, no one can deny her success as both a music star and businesswoman. Her career has been a masterclass in everything from customer connection to innovation, decision-making to digital adaption, offering lessons for people in any industry. HBR senior editor Kevin Evers investigated Swift's rise and evolution for his new book, There's Nothing Like This: The Strategic Genius of Taylor Swift, and found interesting patterns. He explains how she's kept audiences loyal, why her Eras tour was so successful, and the vision and "productive paranoia" that have kept her on top. Evers also wrote the HBR article "The Strategic Genius of Taylor Swift."

title: Apple achieves water replenishment goal for India operations in 2023
description: Apple said that it continued partnership with Frank Water in India last year, which works alongside local partners in India to support access to safe water, sanitation, and hygiene

title: CCI imposes penalties on UFO Moviez, others for anti-competitive practice

title: #2273 What happened to our partnership?
description: Before I partnered with Jesse Pujji, we were buddy-buddy. Texting all the time. When we got started, we got excited about the world of possibilities for our company. Now? Something is missing. I asked him about it. And about where he put his money, why he‚Äôs not launching more companies now, what he‚Äôs building with AI, and more. Jesse Pujji is the founder of Gateway X, the venture studio. Jesse & Andrew are building Bootstrapped Giants, a resource for ambitious, unfunded founders. More interviews -> https://mixergy.com/moreint Rate this interview -> https://mixergy.com/rateint
author: Andrew Warner

title: #2272 Aux: >$10mil advising private equity
description: When Kasey Grelle heard that private equity companies paid marketing agencies to evaluate companies they wanted to buy, she spotted a business opportunity. That realization became Aux Insights, the firm that‚Äôs become ‚Äúthe office of the CMO‚Äù for private equity companies. Listen to how they got clients & built their business. Kasey is a former reporter who founded Aux Insights, a global advisory firm that acts as the office of the CMO for private equity firms, specializing in digital growth strategy and marketing diligence. When she‚Äôs not scaling businesses, she‚Äôs up before dawn at 4 AM, savoring the quiet magic of early morning work before the chaos of her three-kid household kicks in. title: Vizio: William Wang
description: When Wiliam Wang started selling flat-screen TV‚Äôs, he used a winning playbook: partner with an efficient manufacturer, cut out the middlemen, and price your product as low as you can. William used a similar strategy at his first company‚Äìmaking computer monitors‚Äìand he built it into a multimillion dollar business. But he wound up mismanaging it into the ground, and spent years working to pay off millions of dollars in debt. After surviving a catastrophic plane crash, William embarked on a new venture, Vizio, and returned to his ‚Äúcut-out-the-middlemen‚Äù playbook to sell one of the world‚Äôs first internet-connected televisions. Today, Vizio is one of the top-selling TV‚Äôs in the US, and in 2024, sold to Walmart for $2.3 billion.This episode was produced by J.C. Howard, with music by Ramtin Arablouei.Edited by Neva Grant, with research help from Alex Cheng.You can follow HIBT on¬†Twitter¬†&¬†Instagram, and email us at¬†hibt@id.wondery.com. title: Advice Line with Peter Rahal of RXBAR
description: RXBAR co-founder Peter Rahal joins Guy on the Advice Line, where they answer questions from three early-stage founders about positioning new products in competitive markets. Plus, Peter‚Äôs take on getting back in the game with his newest venture, David Protein.¬†First we meet Kristi from Calgary, who‚Äôs considering digital ads as¬† her women‚Äôs supplements brand maxes out on organic growth. Then Erik from Los Angeles, who‚Äôs wondering if Amazon is a necessary channel¬† for his exercise accessories. And April from New York, who‚Äôs hoping to find the right messaging for her line of cocktail mixers.Thank you to the founders of Inner Wellth, SquatWedgiez, and Cheeky Cocktails for being a part of our show.If you‚Äôd like to be featured on a future Advice Line episode, leave us a one-minute message that tells us about your business and a specific question you‚Äôd like answered. Send a voice memo to hibt@id.wondery.com or call 1-800-433-1298.And be sure to listen to RXBAR's founding story as told by Peter in a special live episode of How I Built This from 2018.This episode was produced by Chris Maccini with music by Ramtin Arablouei. It was edited by John Isabella. title: Turf Wars, Tree Men & Murder: Inside the world of Christmas tree selling in NYC
description: Christmas trees are big business in NYC. Running a tree lot takes grit and experience, and even then, it's a tough network to break into. All of the lots in the city are divided into separate territories, owned by only a handful of entrepreneurs. We spent the day working for NYC's busiest Christmas tree seller on Greg Walsh's busiest day of the year to better understand the wild logistics behind NYC‚Äôs Christmas tree economy and the tumultuous history of running a lot in this city. Get the Side Hustle Ideas Database: https://clickhubspot.com/ogv
author: HubSpot

title: What does winning a James Beard Award really mean for chefs?
description: Often called the Oscars of the food industry, the James Beard Foundation Awards are among the most coveted for chefs in America. But what's sold and packaged as prestige can sometimes become a distraction from managing the business that got you there. Host Matt Brown is joined by The New York Times food critic Brett Anderson & chef Chintan Pandya (Dhamaka, Semma, Adda, Unapologetic Foods) to learn that an award can not only change a winner's life but an entire industry as a whole.
author: HubSpot
